notesStmt.note: Dedication to "Ieane Hammiltone, Ladie Skirling" is dated "From Cambusnethane the xxv of December".
Verse "To the author" signed: W.A. of Menstrie [i.e. William Alexander, afterwards Earl of Stirling].
Imperfect: print bleeding and show-through with loss of text.
Reproduction of original in: National Library of Scotland.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

q.p: Ingre≈ø≈øus igitur Angelus ad eam, dixit, Aue grat√¨s dilecta, dominus tecum e≈øt, benedicta tu inter mulieres.

div.p: EDINBVRGH PRINTED BY ROBERT CHARTERIS Printer to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øtie. An. Dom. MDCV.

div.head: TO THE AVTHOR.
div.l: GO pro≈øecute that ≈øacred cour≈øe of thine,
And v≈øe the ≈øubiect that's vnu≈øde too long.
The frutefull trea≈øures of a rich Ingyne,
That's ≈øpent approuing right di≈øprouing vvrong,
May make diuinitie ≈øeeme more diuine:
Whilst by a raui≈øhde ≈øoule diuinelie ≈øong:
This in all myndes doth great delight infu≈øe,
To heare things heauenlie of an heauenlie mu≈øe.

div.head: TO THE HONOVRABLE LADIE OF HIGHEST HOPE MISTRESSE Ieane Hammiltone, Ladie Skirling.
div.p: HOnourable Ladie, hauing nothing of vvorth to pre≈øent your Ladi≈øhippe, I haue pre≈øumde to offer to the Schryne of your gratious clemencie the humble ≈øacrifice of my deuote ≈øinceritie: vvhereby I haue bevvrayed rather a vvill to obey, then any skill to de≈øerue your Ladi≈øhips protection. For (vvell I vvotte) the≈øe fevv di≈øordered lynes are too vveake a prop to beare the burthene of your al-fleing fame. Yet calling to mynde your Ladi≈øhips vvorthie di≈øpo≈øition, I am per≈øvvaded my attempts vvill rather be buryed in ≈øilence, nor ≈ømyled at vvith di≈ødaine, and the rather be bucaus I am obligate your Ladie≈øhips in all devvties euer and euer.

closer.dateline: From Cambu≈ønethane the xxv of December.

div.head: INVOCATION.
div.l: WHat tyme the Cock vvith vvyde di≈øplayed vving
Did beate his breast, and then proclame the day:
His peir≈øing note vnto my thoughts did bring
My devvties all, and fir≈øt hovv I ≈øhould pray.
Then on my knees I turnde me vvhere I lay,
With mourning ≈øpeech euen thus I did begin:
O Lord, I thee be≈øeech thy iu≈øtice ≈øtay:
Call not to mynde the lyfe I liued in.
Grant me thy spirite that I may rightlie rin
∆≤nto that Lambe that did thine regor mea≈øe,
To off ‚Ä¢ r thee by him for highe≈øt ≈øin
A broken heart for burning ≈øacrifyce:
Then I be≈øought that all the three in one,
The vvorke vvould ble≈ø≈øe my pen had vndergone.

div.head: TO THE HONOVRED LADIE OF HIGHEST HOPE MISTRESSE IEANE HAMmiltone Ladie Skirling.

lg.l: NOT to the vvorldling vvaltring in his vvealth,
Nor to the v≈øurer recounts his gaine:
Not to the ≈øicke, vvho≈øe thoght is on his health,
Nor to the in≈øolent of lyfe prophane:
Not to the ignorant of bruti≈øh braine,
Nor to the ≈øtupide Stoick vvill I ≈øend thee:
Not to the learnde, vvho≈øe knovvledge vvith di≈ødaine
Will ≈øcorne the Poet that ≈øo lovvrdlie pende thee:
Not vnto babes, vvho≈øe age cannot defend thee,
Nor ≈øiluer-≈øeeking Min≈øtrels for to ≈øing:
Not vnto careles men, vvho vvhen they end thee,
Vnclo≈øde vvill thee vvithin ≈øome vvindovv ≈øling:
But to a Ladie ≈øvveet I vvill thee offer,
Who hauing reade thee, clo≈ølie vvill thee coffer.
THEN faire≈øt faire, vvho≈øe matchles maners mylde,
And hautie thoughts dimerites high affection:
Who might haue beene the mother of that Childe,
If any Gentile had beene in election.
But ≈øince it is (I ≈øpeake it vvith correction)
Thou art no Ievv, but in the Ievv indented
By grace, loue, mercie and by free adoption
Of that great God our mi≈øerie preuented:
Then prai≈øe his Name the vvay ≈øo vvell inuented,
Prai≈øe thou the ≈øpirite that ≈øanctified the birth,
Prai≈øe Ie≈øus Chri≈øt ≈øo freelie that con≈øented
To cloath his god-hoode vvith the filthie earth:
Prai≈øe all the three, they onely craue Peccaui,
Changde hopeles Eua in an happie Aue.
OVT from the orders of the Angels all
Sings holie hymnes about the throne of grace,
The Lord commands to come vnto his call
The winged Gabriell, ≈øtraight to embrace
An happie charge for Eues vnhappie race:
Who ≈øince hir husbands fall had lyen within
The foule alluring baytes of filthie ≈øin.
Swiftlie he came, ≈øweetlie the Lord did ≈øay,
Thou that hes oft my me≈ø≈øage borne in yre
Kings to de≈øtroy, and countries did deny
My god-hoode great, with hote con≈øuming fyre:
Go now in peace, let all thy rich attyre
Be Azure hew, bright ≈øtarres therein thou fix,
I will my ju≈øtice with my mercie mix.
I will redeeme, recall, I will reclame,
Not by de≈øert, but by adoption;
Not for their merites but my glories Name,
No not compelde, but at my option
The hou≈øe of Iacob by my onelie Sonne,
Borne of a Mayde, and the beleeuers all
That breathes beneath my euer-mouing Ball.
I will perfite my promi≈øe made indeede
To the fir≈øt man through facilnes that fell:
That his begot ≈øhould bru≈øe the ≈øerpents head,
Who≈øe birth in bewtie ≈øhould the re≈øt excell,
Then where that Virgine re≈øts I will thee tell,
Of all the Tribes that I haue taine for cho≈øe,
The famous Nazareth doth her enclo≈øe.
Pure are her thoughts, cha≈øte are her actions all
Firme is her faith, and feruentlie doth pray:
Diuine in Spirite, deuote on me to call:
Re≈øolu'd in heart, at euerie houre to pay
The death her dew, or yet content to ≈øtay:
So are her vertues knowne, ≈øo flyes her fame,
Betrothde ≈øhe is, ble≈øt Marie heght her name.
Salute the mayde with humble dewties dew,
Di≈øcharge my charge with reuerence and feare:
Seene ≈øhall it be (although it ≈øeeme vntrew)
That of my Sonne ≈øhe is the mother deare:
For when with glorie great thou drawes neare
And warbles forth thy voice, thou ≈øhall perceaue
The holie Spirite the Sauiour conceaue.
Thus ≈øaid the Lord, when Eoles windie Fanne
The weeping dew from tender trees had rent,
And when the horned-Moone with vi≈øage wanne
Her borrowed light had back to Tytan ≈øent,
That all the night before he had her lent:
And this he ≈øaid, while all the ho≈øte of heauen
Proclaimde his glore for ≈øuch commi≈ø≈øion giuen.
And hauing ≈øaid, his armes abroad he threw,
And ble≈øt the me≈ø≈øinger before him lay:
Then ≈øilent ≈øat, away the Angell flew,
And in the Aire his wings did wyde di≈øplay:
He claue the cloudes and cut the vapors gray,
He made the heauens admire, the waters wonder,
To ≈øee his glore, and heare his thuds of thunder.
With holie Canticles and hymnes he ≈øings
The ioyfull newes of mans ≈øaluation,
In flames of fyre were grauen betweene his wings
The Birth, the Buriall, and the Pa≈ø≈øion
The Death, the Ry≈øing and Conception,
Of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, yea and the totall ≈øumme
Of all his wondrous works that were to come.
Dronke with delights, ≈øweete Nazareth he ≈øoght,
That place he compa≈øt thryfe aroud and ouer,
In Maries pre≈øence ≈øhortlie is he broght,
Graue was his grace, while he on wing did houer,
At la≈øt his heauen-borne ≈øight he did vncouer:
And with a ≈øhudder all the hou≈øe he ≈øpangled,
With twinkling dew vnto his plumes were tangled.
Amazde at fir≈øt, but not greatlie aga≈øt,
To ≈øee his glorie great, ≈øhe changed hew:
A blu≈øhing rednes ≈øwiftlie came and pa≈øt
And dayntilie her whitenes did ≈øubdew
The lightning rayes that from her eye-lids flew,
When ≈øodaine ioy made tumbling teares ouerflow,
Would ≈øoone haue ≈øet an heape of hearts on low.
The fir≈øt ≈øeene ≈øigne of her trew cha≈øtitie
Round fleeting flew, and cannopyed her skinne,
Two frothie globes of equall quantitie
Playde on her brea≈øt, with vaynes blew, blu≈øhing, thin:
Her tempting mouth aboue her dimpled chin,
Her rankes of pearle, her halfe vp-≈øpreading Ro≈øes
Still other ki≈øt, while ≈øtill each other clo≈øes.
Betweene the branches of her bodie lay
Great Egypts wonders in the holie Print:
Whereon ≈øhe reade, and hauing reade would ≈øtay
To meditate, how Mo≈øes meeke was ≈øent
To that proud Prince, who neuer would repent,
Till all his Chariotes, wheeles and A≈ø≈øle trees
Indented were with ≈øandes amid≈øt the ≈øeyes.
Whiles would ≈øhe turne and ouer-turne the leafe,
Whiles grauelie gather vp ≈øome ≈øentence darke:
Whiles ≈øadlie ≈øit twixt doubting and beleefe,
How the fir≈øt age was clo≈øde within an Arke:
Whiles with her foreme≈øt ioynt ≈øhe would remarke
The trimbling ≈øacrifice that Abram old
Made of his tender Sonne with courage bold.
At la≈øt her heart did kindle vp her ≈øpirite:
Her ≈øpirite commanded both her knees to bow.
On yeelding knees the Lord ≈øhe did intreate,
Her pithie prayers pure he would allow,
Which in his pre≈øence there ≈øhe did avow:
De≈øyring that in heart he would re≈øolue
The apprehen≈øions high ≈øhe did reuolue.
What meanes the brough ≈øo round about her hang,
Who≈øe glancing rayes ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ew Opall changing hewes?
What meanes the winged ≈øpirite ≈øo ≈øweetlie ≈øang,

The ≈øecond Ad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
„Äà‚óä„Äâ with ioyfull newes?
What boy it is my ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ped ≈øpirite „Äà‚óä„Äâ ?
With Angels eyes, what „Äà‚óä„Äâ the≈øe words of mirth
Glorie to God, and peace to „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
At the≈øe her words her „Äà‚óä„Äâ , her „Äà‚óä„Äâ
His beauties blaze forbade her to admire
For loe the ≈øanct, his me≈ø≈øage to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ fold
Proclamde the≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ggied words with ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ yling cheare,
Hayle Virgine pure, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Dauids daughter deare,
Hayle well of „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
The Lambe „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
Hayle Marie mylde repleni≈øhed with grace,
Beloued of God, „Äà‚óä„Äâ of all the „Äà‚óä„Äâ
That of the bleeting Eues of Adams race,
This onelie ble≈ø≈øing great ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ngs to thee:
Then to di≈øcharge thi message giuen to mee,
I ble≈ø≈øe thy actions all, I ble≈ø≈øe thy name,
I ble≈ø≈øe that ble≈ø≈øed babe ≈øprings of thy wambe.
The holie, happie ≈øalutation giuen,
New admirations through her fen≈øes ran,
With thoughts confu≈øde and ≈øtented eyes to heuaen
Vnto the winged Spirite ≈øhe thus began
Am I a mother neuer knew a man?
Or with the ≈øcornefull maydes ≈øhall I be loathed,
Who≈øe onelie fault is this, I was betrothed.
Free flees my thoughts, vn≈øpotted is my fame,
I loath all companie that may allure,
I ballance not my plea≈øures with my ≈øhame:
With Iepthes girle I liue a Virgine pure,
I ≈øcorne to be enrold as Sichems hure:
Therefore the Lord in his appoynted day
Will grant ≈øaluation to this tent of clay.
I neuer went to ≈øee nor to be ≈øeene,
To Tymbrell ≈øound I neuer caroll ≈øong:
I neuer danced in Cabinet nor greene,
Short pa≈ø≈øages, nor mouing Mea≈øures long,
Earings of gold in trea≈ø≈øe neuer hang
Lyke twinkling ≈øtars, I neuer learnde to ≈ømyle
With rolling eyes, nor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ rging ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ earde ≈øtyle.
I neuer ≈øhew my ≈ønow-white ≈øwelling globes,
To giue the in≈øolent the more ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ yte
I neuer walked in ≈øilken ≈øhyning robes,
The feeders: of our fa ‚Ä¢ ill appetyte:
Dittayes of loue I neuer did indyte,
I neuer v≈øde perfumde nor paynted face,
Nor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ted Courtlie beck with min≈øing pace.
No Marie, no, thy ≈øpotles thoughtes are knowne,
Thy faith is ≈øeene to the al-≈øeeing eye:
Through all the earth thy ble≈ø≈øings ≈øhall be ≈øhowne,
Then feare thou not reprochfull in fa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ie,
The Spirite in God ≈øhall ouer-≈øhadow thee:
By him thou ≈øhalt conceaue that Holie one,
That ≈øit for euer ≈øhall on Dauids throne.
Great ≈øhall he be, his Kingdome ≈øhall not moue,
Ouer all the hou≈øe of lacob ≈øhall he ≈øway:
All power ≈øhall be granted him aboue,
The corners of the earth ≈øhall him obey,
The Gentile Kings to him ≈øhall tribute pay
Vpon their knees in honour of his birth,
At Bethlem, with gold, incen≈øe and mirth.
Heauens ≈øoldiers ≈øhall ≈øcumme the tople≈ø≈øe skyes,
And ≈øound the phamphere of his fame on hie:
Prei≈øts, Propheits, Patriarks with holie cryes,
That night about poore ≈øheepherds heads ≈øhall flie:
The Angels and Archangels in degrie,
And winged Cherebins with warbling voice,
Round in a ring ≈øhall mightelie reioyce.
With all the ble≈ø≈øed troupes Hyerarchies,
As powers, thrones and dominations:
Ble≈øt Serphins and Principalities,
Victorious Martyres with immortall Crownes,
Young innocents pure virgine who≈øe renownes
Gain≈øt all a≈ø≈øaults haue keept their cha≈øtitie,
As mid-wyue skild that office ≈øhall ≈øupplie.
Now while the≈øe melodies ≈øhall mountaines moue,
And euerie Angell ≈øhall another leade:
This wonder wondrous for to approue,
Each ≈øheepherd ≈øhall tune on an oaten reade,
With lylting lowde fa≈øt home-ward ≈øhall they ≈øpeede:
And cau≈øe the countrie people all conueene,
To prai≈øe the Lord, for wonders by them ≈øeene.
Then ≈øhall the Ocean tumble vp her ≈øand,
And prea≈øe her bounds to breake, thy Sonne to ≈øee:
The wandring ≈øtarres ≈øhall twinkling ouer him ≈øtand,
Which was the guyde to Herodes Princes three:
The fyrie lampe of heauens blew Cannopie
Le≈øt he be la≈øt his ≈øeruice to aduance,
Shall giue thy babe good-morrow with a glance.
All fle≈øh ≈øhall fold, all Nations ≈øhall haue peace,
Sybillaes prophe≈øies no faith ≈øhall haue.
By him the Delphin Oracle ≈øhall cea≈øe,
The Gentiles gods no longer ≈øhall deceaue:
And if thou would of me this que≈øtion craue,
What name he heght the≈øe errours ≈øhall expell?
Manie they are, but fir≈øt Immanuell.
The Gentiles hope, and Iacobs morning ≈øtarre,
The rocke of rayne, and the corner ≈øtone:
The flower of Ie≈ø≈øe, that doth ≈øent ≈øo farre,
The trew-Me≈ø≈øias and that holie one:
The Prince of peace, the Re≈øurrection
A Chri≈øt, a Ie≈øus and a Sauiour,
A Lambe, a Silo and a great Pa≈øtour.
The furni≈øher of faith, the mercie ≈øait,
The Sanctuarie great of mans refuge,
The Lords annoynted and his rewler great
The word, the way, the Prophete and the Iudge:
The Ruther of the Arke in the deludge:
The bread of lyfe, the Alpha and the end,
The Doue that Noe in his Amba≈ø≈øage ≈øend.
The well of lyfe the bread ≈øent down from heauen,
His Fathers Image bewtifull and faire,
Brightnes it ≈øelfe, to whome all glore is giuen:
The fir≈øt begotten and his Fathers Aire:
The ≈øerpent ≈øtrong the helles all-≈øpuilzier
The bi≈øhoppe of our ≈øoules and brother deare,
Ble≈øt be thy bellie ≈øuch a babe doth beare.
Now while this winged Spirite had told this tale,
The ≈øweete alluring lookes and comelie grace,
The mayde that at his entrie ≈øeemed pale
Shynde lyke the birnei≈øt beames of Tytans face,
Dread left her thoghts, feare gaue high ioy the place,
Her eyes, eares, heart, and tongue were all content
Vnto his happie charge to giue con≈øent.
Thou the Creator of all creature:
That formed the globe, the morning and the nights,
That ≈øet the ≈øeyes, and made the aire ≈øo pure,
That ≈øpangled all the heauens with fyrie lights,
Confirme thy promi≈øe made in all our ≈øights:
And let thy hand-mayde finde that happie ble≈ø≈øing
Which I≈øraels Dames could not obtain by wi≈øhing.
With hy≈ø≈øope purge and purifie my heart,
Direct thy Spirite to cloath me with his wings:
Thy graces great on me, pure me impart,
Mount vp my earthlie thoghts to heauenlie things:
And ≈øince that I euen of the King of Kings,
The mother am, Lord lift my voice on hie,
With ≈øome ≈øweete ≈øong thy name to magnifie.
As this he ≈øaid, the ≈øweete renewing Gho≈øt
Cled with a cloud begouth to doe his dew,
With glorie great he fild the hou≈øe almo≈øt,
Like to a Turtle white his Image grew:
Betwene the Angell and the mayd he flew
With ≈øoft, ≈øweete, ≈øober cour≈øe, and then did light
Betwene her lips, then vani≈øht out of ≈øight:
O far-fetcht fainting breath, √¥ chiuering chin,
O flightring heart, and eyes entombe in teares,
O hollow warbling throate, now now begin
With neuer tyring tune to fill the eares
Of euerie creature my ble≈ø≈øing heares:
O happie ≈øoule, ≈øee thou the≈øe ver≈øes warpe,
Lyke the≈øe ≈øometymes were ≈øung to Dauids Harpe.
THE Heauens eternall al-fore≈øeeing King,
Our thoughts deepe ≈øearcher, Natures father great
The worlds ≈øtrong Mouer, founder of all thing
Within the round and the infernall pit:
Strange graces hes he granted vnto me,
That without ≈øin I ≈øhould ≈øing lullabie.
From high he hes beheld my pure e≈øtate,
And made my flightring Spirite his prai≈øe proclame.
His kindnes hes no periode nor date,
To all him loues, all holie be his name,
The proud he hes de≈øpy≈øed for loue of me,
And bids me ≈øing on high ≈øweete lullabie.
He hes deiect the mightie from their thrones,
And mounted humble hearts of poore≈øt ≈øpirite:
Refre≈øht he hes the hunger-≈øteruing bones
Of ≈øimple ≈øoules lay begging by the ≈øtreete,
He hes ≈øent downe his Angell vnto me,
And bids me rock the babe with lullabie.
That happie promi≈øe now he will fulfill,
